title-group.article-title: Regulation of bicoid mRNA throughout oogenesis and early embryogenesis impacts protein gradient formation

abstract.p: The transcription factor Bicoid (Bcd) establishes patterning in the early Drosophila blastocyst through its graded concentration along the anterior-posterior (AP) axis. bcd mRNA is maternally deposited during oogenesis, yet precisely when and where bcd mRNA is translated remains an open problem. Here, we take advantage of the SunTag reporter system to quantitatively examine the spatiotemporal profile of bcd mRNA translation in vivo. We demonstrate that Processing body (P body) localisation in the oocyte suppresses premature bcd mRNA translation. Upon egg laying, bcd mRNA disassociates from P bodies and translation is observed exclusively in the anterior pole of the embryo. Accompanying nuclear migration to the embryo cortex at nuclear cycle (n.c.) 9, bcd mRNA relocates to the apical domain of the nuclear environment and translation continues near the embryo surface. In n.c. 14, bcd mRNA localises to newly formed P bodies and further translation is not detected. We use these observations to build a modified source-diffusion-degradation model of Bcd gradient formation that leads to an exponential gradient by n.c. 12 and is consistent with other experimental measurements of Bcd dynamics. Consequently, we see that the spatiotemporal dynamics of bcd mRNA translation are highly regulated throughout oogenesis and early embryo development.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The concept of signalling molecules, coined morphogens, that instruct spatial patterning through their spatially inhomogeneous concentration within developing systems was proposed by Turing (1). Downstream target genes respond in a concentration-dependent manner to the morphogen concentration (2). Bcd, a transcription factor present in the early Drosophila blastocyst, was the first identified morphogen gradient (3). A concentration gradient of Bcd extends along the AP axis from highest in the anterior pole of the embryo to around 70% embryo length, with the expression profiles of downstream target genes such as hunchback dependent on the local Bcd concentration (4–6).

Soon after its discovery, the Synthesis, Diffusion, Degradation (SDD) model was proposed as a mechanism for Bcd gradient formation (3, 7). This model assumed localised production of Bcd in the anterior pole, followed by diffusion through the embryo and subsequent degradation. Such a model predicted an exponentially decaying concentration profile in steady state, as observed in vivo (7–9). Yet, there are multiple mechanisms that can generate exponentially decaying morphogen profiles (10, 11). Alternatives to the SDD model include: (i) local production (i.e. translation) of Bcd, by the bcd mRNA (henceforth referred to by bcd) being spatially distributed along the embryo (12); (ii) early translation of bcd in the oocyte, enabling quick spread of the morphogen prior to patterning in later nuclear cycles (13); and (iii) nuclear dilution, which does not require protein degradation (14). These models make distinct predictions for when and where bcd is translated, yet they can all form exponential-like concentration gradients in appropriate parameter regimes at relevant time scales for patterning (15–17).

Localised bcd is first observed in mid-stage oocytes and shows continued enrichment in late oogenesis (18–20). As the egg matures, bcd transitions from continued active transport to stable anchoring at the anterior cortex (20, 21). After oogenesis, all bcd that is required for anterior patterning in the embryo is localised tightly to the anterior cortex of the mature oocyte (Figure 1A) (18–21). There is no current biochemical evidence for bcd translation before egg activation (22–24), a conserved process for a suite of changes in the egg, including re-initiation of meiosis, a change in the translational landscape, and reconfiguration of the cytoskeleton, as the mature egg enters the oviduct prior to fertilisation (25). Translational repression of bcd in the oocyte is thought to be regulated by association with a cytoplasmic biomolecular condensate (26, 27).

Research into condensate function, composition, and physical properties, has largely focused on single cell models and in vitro systems (28–32). These data have provided an excellent foundation for exploring translational regulation via condensates in multicellular organisms. The ability to manipulate condensates genetically and physically in Drosophila has recently been shown to be insightful for deciphering the biological relevance of RNP granules in a developmental context (33–37).

The use of phase-separated droplets as a mechanism for regulating localised translation in the Drosophila oocyte is well illustrated by work on the oocyte posterior. Visualisation of nanos mRNA translation reveals that germ granules can be translation sites or repression dependent on localisation (36). The germ-line determinant oskar (osk) mRNA associates with “solid-like” condensates where its unique secondary structure is required to maintain osk RNA inside the condensates, where it is translationally repressed (33).

A similar model of RNA regulation via association with biomolecular condensates had previously been proposed for bcd (26, 27). Once localised to the anterior, bcd is sequestered in the core of P bodies away from ribosomes (26). P bodies are a conserved condensate that, dependent on the cellular context, have been implicated in the storage and degradation of mRNA (28, 38). A range of proteins involved in mRNA regulation is found to be enriched in P bodies, including DEAD-box family RNA helicase Maternal Effect at 31B (Me31B), which has homologies in other species (DDX6 -humans, Dhh1 - S.cerevisiae, Xp54 - Xenopus, Cgh-1 - C.elegans) (26, 39). Previous work has shown that Me31B functions both in repression and clearance of maternal transcripts in early embryogenesis (40).

With regards to formation of the Bcd morphogen gradient, previous work has typically either focused on the regulation of bcd during oogenesis (26, 41–43) or on the dynamics of Bcd protein post-translation (7, 10, 17, 44, 45). Yet, to gain a more complete understanding of how the Bcd gradient forms requires integrating these two approaches. Here, we utilised the imaging-based SunTag/scFv reporter system (46–53), to quantitatively assay bcd translation in Drosophila oocytes and embryos. In the oocyte, we demonstrate that P body localisation of bcd inhibits translation and dissociation from P bodies results in bcd translation. Upon egg activation, bcd mRNAs are released from the P bodies and we observed rapid onset of bcd translation, strictly limited to the anterior pole of the embryo. Following nuclear migration to the embryo outer membrane (n.c. 9), bcd localisation became more apically positioned, with a corresponding shift in the location of translation. We saw a decrease in bcd translation in n.c. 11 onwards, consistent with observations from assaying the protein levels (54). Finally, we demonstrate that a modified SDD model of Bcd gradient formation, where the source of Bcd changes in both space and time based on experimental observations, is consistent with the observed bcd translation and the Bcd protein gradient.

sec.title: bcd mRNA associated with P bodies in the oocyte until egg activation
sec.p: Previous work analysed the relationship between bcd and P body proteins during oogenesis (26, 27), and postulated that bcd localisation to P bodies is important for translational regulation of the mRNA. To confirm if this relationship is maintained through the mid and late stages of oogenesis, we simultaneously imaged a standard P body marker, Me31B, and bcd (Figure 1B-C). We performed single molecule FISH (smFISH) for bcd in tissue that expresses endogenously tagged Me31B, which is subsequently “boosted” with an anti-GFP-nanobody conjugated to a photostable dye (Methods).

During the transition from mature oocyte to activated egg, P bodies disassembled (26, 27, 55) and Me31B became evenly distributed in the cytoplasm. bcd similarly dispersed and lost its tight association with the anterior cortex (Figure 1D-F). The distribution of bcd was maintained in the early embryo when ‘embryonic’ P bodies appeared to reassemble with unique characteristics compared to those in the oocyte (Figure 1D-F). Based on these results and previous observations (26, 27), we hypothesised that the loss of colocalisation between bcd and P bodies correlates with bcd translation.

sec.title: bcd translation only begins after egg activation
sec.p: To test when and where bcd is translated in the oocyte and embryo, we generated a SunTag-bcd transgene, containing an array of 32X SunTag repeats, referred to here as bcdSun32 (Figure S1, Methods). Prior to exploring the capacity of bcd to be translated in oocytes, we first validated our reporter in fixed early embryos. To this end, we performed immuno-FISH, labelling bcdSun32 as well as the SunTag peptide, recognised by an anti-GCN4 antibody. We also performed this validation in the presence of the fluorescent detector, the single-chain antibody scFV, which is genetically encoded and maternally provided (nos-scFv-MSGFP2) (56).

After validating our bcdSun32 reporter by showing co-localisation between the RNA and protein in early embryos (Figure S1), we genetically expressed bcdSun32 in oocytes. We observed no translation in any region of stage 9 or 14 oocytes (Figure 2A-B), consistent with predictions based on previous observations of bcd localisation to P bodies (26, 27). However, after egg activation, bcd translation occurred rapidly and continued after egg laying (22, 57) (Figure 2C). Consistent with previous observations of bcd localisation (3), we only observed translation in the anterior of the activated egg and early embryo (Figure 2C).

To test whether co-localisation of bcd with P bodies was necessary for its translational repression, we first sought to maintain the relationship between bcd and P bodies through egg activation (Figure 2D-G). We utilised a pharmacological reagent known to disrupt the calcium wave that transverses the activated egg while other phenotypic markers of egg activation are observed (58). Incubation of oocytes with NS8593 caused a failure to disperse P bodies during ex vivo egg activation (Figure 2D). smFISH on NS8593 treated activated oocytes showed that bcd association with P bodies was maintained in large particles close to the anterior margin (Figure 2D,F). Consistent with our predictions, we did not observe translation of bcdSun32 in NS8593 treated activated oocytes (Figure 2E,G). Together, this suggests that P bodies act as a physical barrier that maintains bcd transcripts within a translation-free environment in the oocyte.

sec.title: Premature release of bcd mRNA results in ectopic translation
sec.p: Altering the physical state of a condensate can impact its ability to store mRNA (27, 33, 59). To further test if bcd storage in P bodies is required for translational repression, we monitored mRNA association with P bodies under different chemical treatments known to disrupt condensate integrity (60–62). The addition of Hexanediol or NaCl to mature oocytes resulted in bcd detected outside of P bodies (Figure 3A-C). Following treatment of mature oocytes with these chemicals, we observed BcdSun32 protein in the oocyte anterior (Figure 3D-E). To ensure that the chemical treatments did not inadvertently activate the mature eggs, resulting in translation, we assayed for egg activation (57). Chemically treated eggs did not survive the activation test (63), thus confirming that the storage in P bodies is important to maintain bcd translational repression.

To further challenge this model, we utilised mutations in Drosophila Endosulfine (Endos) (64), which resulted in a similar change in condensate phenotype at egg maturation as those observed with chemical treatments (Figure 3F). This temporal effect was consistent with the known roles of Endos, part of the conserved phosphoprotein α-endosulfine (ENSA) family, which has been previously described as the master regulator of oocyte maturation in Drosophila (64, 65). Endos mutant oocytes showed a loss of colocalisation between bcd and P bodies, concurrent with the transition to a less viscous P body state at oocyte maturation (Figure 3F-G, Figure S2). Particle size and positional analysis showed bcd RNPs undergoing a premature transition to an embryo distribution (Figure 3H-I). Due to genetic and antibody constraints, we are unable to test for translation of bcd in the Endos mutant by immunofluorescence or Western blot. However, based on our SunTag and smFISH data presented here, we posit that bcd observed in this diffuse distribution outside of P bodies would be translationally active (Figure 3F-H).

sec.title: bcd translation is spatially restricted during early Drosophila embryogenesis
sec.p: We next asked when and where bcd is translated in the embryo. Specifically, is bcd translation restricted to the anterior pole and when is the maximum translation rate reached?

We considered that the size of bcdSun32 may impede mRNA biogenesis and the function of SunTag-bcd as a transcription factor. Therefore, we generated a second transgene with fewer SunTag repeats (10x), referred to as bcdSun10 (Figure S3). bcdSun10 rescued the bcdE1 null mutant, suggesting that the tag does not significantly impact function (Figure S3). We performed Immuno-smFISH on bcdSun10 and bcd in n.c. 4 (Figure 4A), to explore the spatial pattern of Bcd protein production. We saw a strong correlation between bcd and sites of translation in the anterior (Figure 4B), with no observable translation greater than 75μm from the anterior pole. The Bicoid gradient has small but reproducible differences between dorsal and ventral surfaces (4). Consistent with this, we saw that the translation profile differed from dorsal to ventral sides (Figure 4A lower panels) as the extent of bcd spread is uneven.

We next quantified the number of translation events in n.c. 4 (Methods, Figure S4) in different regions. We found that in the anterior region of the embryo (<50 μm from the pole), above 90% of overall bcd particles are engaged in translation (Figure 4C-C’). Over 98% of all observed translation events occurred within 50 μm of the anterior pole, with almost none seen beyond 100 μm.

In the cross-sectional view, bcd is distributed steeply along the apical-basal axis with the majority of bcd localised to within 10-12 μm from the embryo’s surface (Figure S5A-B). We do not observe any variation with depth from the surface in the rate of bcd translation (Figure S5C-D). Overall, we did not see evidence for spatial differences in the translation efficacy. We conclude that during early embryogenesis before nuclear migration to the cortex, bcd translation is strictly localised to the anterior domain (<50 μm from the anterior pole).

sec.title: Spatiotemporal pattern of bcd translation
sec.p: We analysed 3D image stacks at different stages of embryo development from n.c.4 to late n.c. 14. In the early embryo (<n.c.9), bcd translation occurred in a broad strip near the embryo cortex in the anterior (Figure 5A). There was sustained translation of bcd. After nuclear migration to the periphery in n.c. 9, we observed a gradual decrease in translation events (Figure 5A-B). By late n.c. 14, translation events were barely detected (Figure 5A-B).

mRNA translation can depend on location within the cytoplasm. For example, twist mRNA residing apical to the nuclei had lower translation compared to basal mRNAs (51). Before cortical migration of nuclei, bcd translation did not show variation from the surface to up to 10 μm from the surface (Figure S5C-D). Does the domain of bcd translation vary upon nuclear migration to the periphery? Interestingly, we observed that after the cortical migration, the number of bcd translation events showed differences with respect to localisation above and below the nuclei (Figure 5C). Upon cortical migration, we also noticed that bcd localisation in the anterior pole became more dispersed (Figure S6). The interphase nuclei and their subsequent mitotic divisions appeared to displace bcd towards the apical surface (Figure S6A-B).

We can directly test different models of Bcd protein production (3, 10, 12, 54) and how this impacts the formation of the Bcd morphogen gradient. After translation, a gradient of Bcd needs to form. We compared the concentration profiles between bcd and the protein distribution in our bcdSun10 line. In the anterior pole, in the cytoplasm, we observed localisation of bcd with our SunTag reporter (Figure S7). The nuclear profile of Bcd protein extended further than the bcd mRNA gradient (Figure S7A’), consistent with an SDD-like model of gradient formation. Further, >98% of all translation events happen within 50μm of the anterior pole (n=3 embryos) regardless of nuclear cycle. The efficiency of translation could vary at different positions in the embryo. We quantified the intensity of translation events along the anterior-posterior axis, but did not observe any clear changes in translation intensity at individual locations (Figure 5D-E). Together, these results suggest that a long-ranged gradient of Bcd production does not occur at any time through n.c. 4-14.

Overall, we see a steady shift in the domain of bcd translation, which correlates with nuclei movements during the blastocyst stage. However, this shift does not result in more dispersed bcd translation along the AP axis. There is a significant reduction in translation, especially from n.c. 13 onwards.

sec.title: bcd mRNA degradation in n.c. 14 (stage 5) embryos
sec.p: After the translation decrease, bcd is completely degraded during n.c. 14 (Figure 6A-C) (12, 66). The colocalisation of mRNAs with embryonic P bodies is correlated with degradation (67–69). To test whether bcd was being targeted for degradation in embryonic P bodies, we observed and analysed bcd and Me31B before, during, and after n.c. 14 (Figure 6A-C). smFISH revealed an even distribution of bcd on the apical and basal side of the nuclei, which did not colocalise with P bodies prior to n.c. 14 (Figure 6A).

At the start of n.c. 14, bcd was localised to the apical side of the nuclei (12), where we observed colocalisation with embryonic P bodies that were also enriched on the apical side (Figure 6B,D-E). As the embryo transitioned into gastrulation, we observed a significant loss of bcd while embryonic P bodies remained (Figure 6C-D,F). Together, this supports a model whereby rapidly degrading mRNAs present in the embryo are localised to embryonic condensates for degradation as the embryo transitions to zygotic control (67–69).

sec.title: Adapted SDD model of Bcd protein gradient formation
sec.p: Formation of the Bcd morphogen gradient has been extensively modelled (11, 15, 70). Yet, previous models typically considered the rate of Bcd production to be constant throughout early embryogenesis. We next asked whether accounting for the spatiotemporal pattern of bcd translation within the SDD model was consistent with the observed Bcd gradient.

We considered the concentrations of bcd mRNA (denoted by [bcd]) and the protein [Bcd], where the concentrations are functions of both space and time, within a modified SDD model (Figure 7A): (Eq. 1a)∂[bcd]∂t=−α(t)[bcd] (Eq.1b)∂[Bcd]∂t=∂∂x[D(x)⋅∂[Bcd]∂x]−μ[Bcd]+β[bcd]
We defined time t =0 to denote egg activation. The initial conditions for [bcd] and [Bcd] were given by (Eq. 2a)[bcd](t=0,x)=f(x) (Eq. 2b)[Bcd](t=0,x)=0

bcd was localised in the anterior pole with a form denoted by f(x), (Eq. 2a), shown in Figure 7B(i). We incorporated a delay initially in translation to account for egg activation (Figure 7B(ii)). The rate of bcd degradation a(t) increased markedly in n.c. 14 (Figure 7B(iii)). It was recently observed that the effective diffusivity of Bcd varies between the anterior and posterior pole (45). We included this through spatial variation in the diffusion coefficient D(x) (Figure 7B(iv)). We assumed that the rate of bcd translation (β) (after egg activation) and Bcd degradation (μ) remained constant. The degradation rate for Bcd has been measured previously based on protein lifetime measurements (10).

Our modified one-dimensional SDD model generated an exponential-like gradient of Bcd in n.c. 13 (Figure 7C-C’). We emphasise that all the parameters in this model are constrained by experimental measurement, except for β, so it is not over parameterised (Table S6). We found a decay length of around 85-95 μm, consistent with experimental measurements (7, 10, 54). By including more realistic bcd translation within the model, the overall behaviour of the Bcd protein gradient (Figure 7D-D’) is consistent with previous observations (54) and our quantification here.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: We have provided a quantitative dissection of when and where bcd is translated in early Drosophila development. Translation is restricted to post egg laying by localisation within P bodies in the oocyte. Translation occurs in the anterior pole of the embryo and undergoes a marked decrease after n.c. 11. Around this time, bcd becomes localised to the apical domain and is rapidly degraded, especially in n.c. 14. This rapid degradation of bcd correlates with its localisation to P bodies during cellularisation. We show that these observations, in concert with recent quantification of Bcd dynamics (45), are consistent with a modified SDD model of gradient formation.

In early embryos, Bcd protein is only observed in the anterior pole. This corresponds tightly with the pattern of bcd translation; no significant translation was observed >50μm from the embryo anterior. These results argue against bcd translation in the oocyte, resulting in long-ranged protein dispersal. Another model has proposed that bcd is distributed through the embryo and hence can generate a long-ranged gradient of Bcd without the need for diffusive transport (12, 71, 72). However, we observe the vast majority of translation events only occurred within 50 μm of the embryo anterior pole. Consistent with previous reports (54), we posit this is due to bcd localisation in the anterior region (<100μm), rather than there being regulation impacting bcd translation in more posterior regions. Consequently, any graded form of bcd translation appears to be largely localised to the anterior; this suggests that a long-ranged bcd translation gradient does not determine the Bcd protein gradient extent.

We noticed distinct differences in the apical-basal localisation of bcd, especially after nuclear migration to the embryo cortex. This alteration in apical-basal distribution correlates with a reduction in the observed bcd translation. However, whether the localisation of bcd impacts its rate of translation remains to be tested further. The localisation of mRNAs within the microenvironment defined by each nuclear domain can impact translation in n.c. 14 (51), though whether a similar effect occurs earlier in development is unclear.

The rapid loss of bcd in n.c. 14 has been previously quantified (54) and here we discovered it also correlates tightly with localisation to P bodies (Figure 6). What determines the model of bcd degradation in n.c. 14? Is it due to global degradation of maternal mRNA or because of a specific regulation of bcd mRNA (40)? Testing for bcd degradation is challenging. One method is to use different smFISH probes for the 5’ and 3’ UTRs and use differences in the spectral signal to infer degradation (69, 73). However, the bcd 5’ UTR is very short, and we were unable to make effective smFISH probes. One possible alternative is to target the bcd instability element (BIE). This regulates degradation of bcd (66) and is located within the more accessible 3’ UTR.

It will be interesting to probe further the functional effects of differences in P bodies between the oocyte and during cellularisation. The P bodies appear to switch function, from shielding bcd from translation to enhancing degradation. Prior to cellularisation, we found that Me31B condensates were insensitive to cycloheximide. However, after cellularisation begins, they become sensitised to cycloheximide (74), suggesting a change in their structure. Relatedly, due to the conserved nature and wide-ranging downstream effects, it is intriguing to consider the possibility that Endos is a condensate regulator both within Drosophila eggs as well as more generally.

Over 40 years of work span from the original proposition of the SDD model for Bcd gradient formation. Here, we quantitatively assay the production of Bcd in vivo, which is arguably the last piece required to understand Bcd gradient formation. We see that the SDD model as originally proposed was too simple, but with suitable modifications – e.g., spatially varying diffusion and temporally altering translation – it can explain the formation of the Bcd gradient.

sec.title: Generation of SunTag bcd transgenic fly lines
sec.p: bcdSun32 was generated by replacing N-terminal eGFP of eGFP:Bcd-pCaSpeR4 construct (kindly gifted by Thomas Gregor (7)) by 32xSunTag repeats (kindly gifted by Mounia Lagha (51)). The 32xSunTag fragments are flanked by NheI and SpeI restriction sites at their N and C-terminal ends respectively by PCR, and then ligated into the eGFP:Bcd construct, replacing eGFP. Likewise, the first 10xSunTag repeats of 32xSunTag were ligated in the same way to generate bcdSun10 construct (Figure S1A). Both Bcd SunTag constructs from the donor pCaSpeR4 construct were recombined into w+attB construct (addgene 30326) and flies were generated by phiC31 recombination into attP40 site of chromosome 2. The injection and generation of fly lines were done by BestGene Inc. USA.

The bcdSun10 fly lines were crossed to the bcd null allele mutant, bcdE1. bcdSun10;bcdE1 fly lines were viable, suggesting our construct can, at least partially, complement the function of endogenous Bcd. smFISH was carried out to test if bcdSun10;bcdE1 effectively replaced the function of endogenous Bcd in the blastoderm. Stellaris smFISH probes with distinct fluorophores were used for SunTag and bcd coding regions of the bcdSun10 mRNA. This enabled us to confirm that the only contribution of maternal bcd mRNA was from our bcdSun10 in the bcdE1 background (Figure S2). Colocalisation analysis in the early blastoderm revealed ~90% of the mRNA were accounted for bcdSun10 (Figure S2B). Further, the immunostaining of the blastoderm embryos with anti-GCN4 antibody revealed the translocation of the bcdSun10 into the nuclei, unlike bcdSun32, eventually forming an anterior posterior gradient similar to endogenous Bcd (Figure S2C-E).

sec.title: Preparation of oocytes
sec.p: Twenty female flies and ten male flies of the correct genotype were transferred into a vial containing fly food supplemented with yeast and were incubated at 25°C for forty-eight hours before dissection (75).

sec.title: Oocyte dissection
sec.p: Fattened or aged female flies were anaesthetised, and the posterior tip of the abdomen was removed using a set of fine forceps. The ovaries were then removed from the open posterior end by squeezing the abdomen (75).

sec.title: Fly husbandry and preparation of embryos
sec.p: Fly stocks were maintained at 21°C in vials that contained standard cornmeal starch agar fly food. To collect flies for experimentation or for genetic crosses, twenty females (virgin females were used for genetic crosses) and ten males were transferred into a plastic bottle containing yeasted cornmeal starch agar fly food at 25°C. Either virgin females or males from this generation were used for additional genetic crosses, or females younger than 10 days old were selected for experimentation. Collected embryos were dechorionated in 50% bleach for 2 minutes before excess bleach was removed with distilled water.

sec.title: Chemical and pharmacological treatments of oocytes
sec.p: Hexanediol and sodium chloride: Dissected oocytes were incubated for 20 minutes in 5% 1,6-HD, 5% 2,5-HD, or 400 mM NaCl before immediate fixation. As controls, dissected oocytes were incubated in PBS or SIM for equal amounts of time before fixation.

in vitro activation of stage 14 oocytes (fixed): Dissected stage 14 oocytes were incubated in activation buffer (AB), for 30 minutes at room temperature. Activated oocytes were incubated in SIM for 0-30 minutes. To ensure that only activated oocytes were visualised, oocytes were treated with 50% bleach for two minutes. The activated oocytes were then fixed using the embryo fixation method. As a control, oocytes were incubated in SIM for the same time period.

Drugs that inhibit the calcium wave: Dissected stage 14 oocytes were incubated in SIM that contained NS8593 for 30 minutes. The oocytes were then activated in vitro following the same steps as above, with all solutions containing the pre-incubation drug. As a control, oocytes were incubated in SIM (with no AB step) with the drug. Additionally, oocytes were incubated in SIM, followed by AB, followed by SIM with a 1:1000 dilution of either DMSO or ethanol.

sec.title: Fixation
sec.p: Oocytes were incubated 1 ml of 4% paraformaldehyde for 15 minutes before immediate washing with 0.1% PBST (76). 10-20 pairs of ovaries were dissected and transferred to room-temperature Schneider’s Insect Medium (SIM). Ovaries were teased apart using dissecting probes until single ovarioles and oocytes were released.

Embryos were transferred into an Eppendorf tube that contains equal parts paraformaldehyde and heptane for 15-30 minutes, depending on the probes or antibodies used, before the paraformaldehyde phase was removed and replaced with 100% methanol. The sample was then shaken vigorously before all the solution was removed. Embryos were then rinsed with methanol and/or ethanol before being washed in 0.1% PBST (76).

sec.title: Single molecule fluorescence in situ hybridisation (smFISH)
Probe design
sec.p: Custom 20 nucleotide Stellaris FISH Probes were designed against the 3’ UTR of bcd, coding region of bcd, and 32x SunTag by utilising the Stellaris RNA FISH Probe Designer and were the same as designed in (65) (Biosearch Technologies, Inc - www.biosearchtech.com/stellarisdesigner). 32x SunTag and bcd 3’UTR Probes were labelled with Quasar 570 and endogenous bcd is labelled with Quasar 670 were ordered for smFISH from Biosearch Technologies, Inc.

sec.title: Buffers
sec.p: Wash buffer was created by mixing the commercially available ‘Wash Buffer A’, de-ionised formamide and nuclease free water in a 2:1:7 ratio or was made using 2% sodium citrate buffer (SSC)+10% formamide. Hybridisation Buffer was created by mixing ‘Stellaris Hybridisation Buffer’ with de-ionised formamide in a 9:1 ratio.

sec.title: Hybridisation
sec.p: The hybridisation protocol was adapted from (51, 54). Briefly, fixed oocytes or embryos were permeabilised with 0.2% triton X-100 and washed in PBST. When necessary, embryos were blocked in PBST+RNase inhibitor+0.5% ultrapure BSA for 45 mins, before being washed in a ‘wash buffer’ solution. The samples were then pre-incubated in hybridisation buffer for two hours at 37°C. The hybridisation buffer was removed and replaced by the hybridisation buffer with smFISH probes for overnight incubation at 37°C, when using anti-GCN4 antibodies in conjunction with smFISH, primary antibodies were incubated overnight in the hybridisation buffer (56). The samples were then washed in hybridisation buffer before repeated washes in prewarmed wash buffer, when using anti-GCN4 antibodies in conjunction with smFISH, secondary antibodies were incubated with the final wash buffer wash, before being washed in 2X SSC. Finally, all samples were washed multiple times in 0.1% PBST.

sec.title: Immunostaining
sec.p: Nanobody labelling on oocytes or embryos, samples were blocked in a 4% BSA solution and then incubated with nanobodies, either GFP booster or RFP booster, in 0.1% PBST for one hour at room temperature. For anti-GCN4 immunostaining not in conjunction with smFISH, samples were incubated for two hours with the primary antibody, followed by washing with 0.1% PBST and incubation with the secondary antibody for two hours. After incubation, all samples were washed with 0.1% PBST.

Washed samples were transferred to a microscope slide and positioned using a dissecting probe. Excess PBST was removed before a single drop of Slowfade Diamond with DAPI or Prolong Diamond with antifade was added to the sample. A 22 x 22 mm coverslip was lowered onto the sample, and the coverslip was sealed with nail varnish and laid flat in the dark for 24 hours before imaging.

sec.title: Imaging
sec.p: All oocyte imaging was completed on an Olympus FV3000 inverted confocal microscope. Embryo imaging was performed on Olympus FV3000 or Olympus Spinning Disc systems. All images were taken using silicone oil 30x (0.95 NA) or 60x (1.4 NA) objectives. A region of interest was placed around either a whole single oocyte or embryo (30x objective) or a specific region of the oocyte or embryo (60x objective), Images were taken at a resolution of 1024 by 1024, or 2048 by 2048 pixels. 405, 488, 561 and 640 nm lasers were used. Laser power was adjusted to ensure that there was a full range of grey values and that the saturation of pixels was limited.

The images for the quantification of bcd foci in the embryo and their colocalisation to translating SunTag, were acquired on an Olympus FV3000 confocal microscope with the following conditions: 60x magnification, 4x zoom, 2 line averaging, slice thickness of 0.4 μm. The regions of high, moderate, and low dense bcd foci from the anterior domain and a very low bcd region in the posterior were imaged for a total thickness of 10-15 μm.

sec.title: Fixed Imaging
sec.p: Optimised step-size Z-stacks of fixed egg and embryos were collected; all Z-were started at the cortex and extended 10-15 μm into the oocyte or embryo. For co-localisation studies, smFISH, and SunTag translation assays, where maximum resolution was imperative. Imaging parameters were optimised to improve resolution: 60 x objective used; pinhole: 1 airy unit; scan speed – 400 Hz; 2x line averaging; 2048 by 2048 pixels; and optimised Z-step (300 nm) (52).

sec.title: Image Analysis
sec.p: Translation quantification: High-resolution image stacks were segmented to identify specific bcd foci. We used the trainable Weka segmentation plugin of ImageJ to train and classify the bcd foci. A classifier model created from a single image slice was applied to the Z-stack, thus classifying the bcd through the whole stack. The segmented particles were analysed using the Fiji particle analysis plugin that provided information on the size, shape, intensity and counts of all particles. The crowded particles that failed to segment properly, which was often the case within highly dense bcd regions, were not considered. We also excluded foci with low brightness. The segmented ROIs of bcd foci were applied to the anti-GCN4 channel. The mean intensities from anti-GCN4 channel were background corrected, and the positive mean values provided the number of colocalising SunTag to bcd particles i.e., these particles were translating bcd (Figure 4D). The plots were made in Graphpad Prism 8.0.

When automated methods were not accurate for detecting partial co-localisation (77), manual analyses were undertaken on images with only partial co-localisation. Images for both channels were thresholded, then an overlay of the threshold outline for channel one (bcd) was projected onto the channel two image (anti-GCN4). The number of particles in bcd channel that overlapped particles in anti-GCN4 channel was counted, and vice versa. To ensure that this partial co-localisation was not due to chance, images of one channel were inverted and the analysis was completed again.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: n numbers: 10 to 20 females or 30 embryos (biological repeats) were used for each experiment and a global overview of the experimental results was acquired by visualising 20-30 oocytes or 30 embryos for each experimental condition unless stated otherwise. A smaller number of representative oocytes were subjected to high resolution imaging and analysis as described above. The “n” used in figures represents independent oocyte or embryo samples.
All statistical analyses were performed in R. For all statistical analyses, asterisks represent the following n.s. not significant * P<0.05, ** P<0.01, *** P<0.001.

Continuous data: Tests for normality were completed before proceeding with the appropriate parametric or non-parametric test. For comparison between two groups, an unpaired student t-test (STT) or a Wilcoxon signed-rank test (WSRT) was used.

Categoric data: A χ2 test (CST) or Fisher’s exact test (FET) was used to determine if there were significant differences between groups. This depended on sample size Fisher’s exact test is preferred for small sample sizes (<50).
